definitions: An eating disorder characterized by restriction of energy intake leading to significantly low body weight.
A condition involving intense fear of weight gain and persistent behaviors that interfere with weight gain.
A disorder marked by distorted body image and undue influence of weight/shape on self-evaluation.
Clinically significant underfueling driven by weight/shape concerns, resulting in medical and performance consequences.
A psychiatric eating disorder where dietary restriction is central and body weight becomes dangerously low.
A pattern of chronic caloric restriction accompanied by strong anxiety about gaining weight.
An eating disorder where low body weight is maintained through restriction and maladaptive beliefs about body size.
A restrictive eating disorder that can cause endocrine, cardiovascular, and skeletal complications due to low energy availability.
An eating disorder marked by recurrent binge episodes with loss of control.
Repeated consumption of unusually large amounts of food in a discrete period, accompanied by perceived inability to stop.
Binge eating that occurs without regular compensatory behaviors like purging.
A clinical condition involving frequent binge episodes and distress about binge eating.
Recurrent overeating episodes characterized by rapid eating and feeling out of control.
Binge eating episodes followed by guilt or distress but not by routine vomiting/laxative use.
A disorder defined by binge frequency and psychological distress rather than compensatory behaviors.
An eating disorder involving loss-of-control eating episodes that can impair health, mood, and performance.
A weight-to-height index used to classify weight status: kg divided by m squared.
A screening metric calculated as body mass (kg) / height (m)^2.
A simple ratio used to estimate weight category in adults (underweight/normal/overweight/obesity).
A population-level classification tool that does not directly measure body fat percentage.
A surrogate measure for weight status that can misclassify muscular athletes.
A height-adjusted body mass index used in health risk stratification.
A standardized anthropometric measure used widely in epidemiology and clinical screening.
A body-size metric useful for groups but limited for individuals with atypical muscle mass.
An eating disorder involving recurrent binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors.
Binge episodes paired with purging (vomiting/laxatives/diuretics) or excessive exercise/fasting.
A disorder marked by loss-of-control eating and attempts to prevent weight gain.
Recurrent binge–compensation cycles with undue influence of body shape/weight on self-evaluation.
An eating disorder where binge eating is followed by behaviors designed to offset caloric intake.
A condition characterized by binge eating plus compensatory actions, often with normal or near-normal body weight.
A psychiatric disorder involving frequent binges and repeated compensatory strategies driven by weight/shape concerns.
An eating disorder where the binge–purge cycle can lead to electrolyte imbalance, GI issues, and performance decline.
A strategy to increase muscle glycogen stores before prolonged endurance events.
Combining a training taper with higher carbohydrate intake to maximize glycogen availability.
A pre-event fueling method designed to improve performance in long-duration exercise.
A nutrition approach that elevates muscle carbohydrate stores to delay fatigue.
A protocol that reduces training volume while increasing carbohydrate to supercompensate glycogen.
A precompetition diet adjustment to enhance endurance capacity by increasing stored carbohydrate.
A performance strategy used before events typically lasting ~90 minutes or longer.
A glycogen-maximizing approach that improves sustained high-output performance by increasing carbohydrate reserves.
Energy expenditure associated with digesting, absorbing, transporting, metabolizing, and storing nutrients.
The increase in metabolic rate after eating due to processing food.
The caloric cost of nutrient processing and assimilation.
A component of total daily energy expenditure driven by food intake.
Post-meal energy expenditure required for digestion and nutrient storage.
The metabolic “overhead” of eating and processing macronutrients.
Energy burned as a direct result of food consumption and metabolism.
A measurable rise in energy expenditure after meals reflecting the cost of handling nutrients.
A spectrum of irregular eating behaviors that may not meet clinical criteria for an eating disorder.
Problematic eating patterns that impair health or performance without necessarily qualifying as a diagnosis.
Maladaptive eating behaviors such as chronic restriction, rigid rules, or recurrent binges without full diagnostic threshold.
Eating behaviors that are unhealthy, inflexible, or psychologically driven, potentially progressing to clinical disorders.
Subclinical eating-related behaviors that can harm energy availability, recovery, and mental health.
Irregular or extreme dietary practices that negatively affect functioning.
Unhealthy eating attitudes and behaviors that exist on a continuum of severity.
Patterns of eating that disrupt physical health, training quality, or psychological well-being.
Clinical conditions characterized by persistent disturbances in eating behaviors and related thoughts/emotions.
Psychiatric disorders involving dysfunctional eating patterns that impair health and daily functioning.
Diagnosable conditions such as anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge-eating disorder.
Mental health disorders defined by maladaptive eating behaviors and distress or impairment.
Sustained eating-related disturbances that compromise physiological health and psychosocial functioning.
Disorders involving abnormal eating behaviors and body-related beliefs leading to medical risk.
Clinical syndromes marked by disordered intake patterns and problematic weight/shape concerns.
A category of mental health conditions where eating behavior disruptions produce significant physical and psychological harm.
Having the same caloric (energy) content.
Equal total energy intake between diets or experimental conditions.
A comparison where calorie intake is matched while macronutrient composition may differ.
Describing diets or meals that provide the same total kilocalories.
Energy-matched conditions used to isolate effects of macronutrient differences.
Same-calorie dietary conditions used in nutrition research.
Equivalent caloric intake across two or more diets or protocols.
A term indicating energy intake is held constant while other variables change.
A condition of excess body fat that increases health risk.
A chronic state commonly classified in adults as BMI ≥ 30 kg/m² (context dependent).
Excess adiposity associated with increased risk of cardiometabolic disease.
A health condition characterized by elevated body fatness and related complications.
A clinical classification often based on BMI thresholds but not a direct fat measure.
A state of high body fat that can impair health, function, and sometimes performance.
A condition linked to increased inflammation and chronic disease risk.
Excess adipose tissue accumulation that elevates morbidity and mortality risk.
A meal eaten before an event intended to optimize energy availability and comfort.
Pre-event nutrition emphasizing familiar foods, adequate fluids, and typically higher carbohydrate.
A meal designed to top off fuel stores while minimizing GI distress.
A pre-performance eating strategy supporting stable blood glucose and hydration.
Food intake before competition intended to enhance readiness and reduce hunger.
A planned meal that supports glycogen availability and athlete comfort prior to an event.
A pre-event feeding approach that prioritizes digestibility and carbohydrate availability.
A meal timed before competition to support energy, hydration, and gastrointestinal tolerance.
Dehydration that occurs because an individual does not drink enough to match fluid losses.
Fluid deficit caused by underdrinking despite available fluids.
Dehydration resulting from inadequate intake relative to sweat/urine losses.
A hydration shortfall due to poor thirst response or behavioral choices.
Underconsumption of fluids leading to a net body water deficit.
A common exercise-related dehydration pattern where thirst lags behind actual need.
Dehydration caused by insufficient drinking rather than forced restriction.
A state where fluid intake fails to replace ongoing losses, producing measurable hypohydration.
